entry.title: Wind Advisory issued April 12 at 10:17AM EDT until April 13 at 7:00AM EDT by NWS Charleston WV
entry.summary:
* WHAT...West winds 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.
* WHERE...Southeast Pocahontas County.
* WHEN...Until 7 AM EDT Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will blow around unsecured objects. Tree limbs could be blown down and a few power outages may result.

cap:parameter.value: WIND ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 AM EDT SATURDAY

entry.summary:

* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will blow around unsecured objects. Tree limbs could be blown down and a few power outages may result.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued April 12 at 6:12AM AKDT until April 12 at 12:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow and blowing snow occuring. Additional snow accumulations of 2 to 4 inches. South winds gusting to 35 mph will reduce visibility to one half miles or less at times.
* WHERE...Southern Denali Borough and Eastern Alaska Range South of Trims Camp.
* WHEN...Until noon AKDT today.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Denali Borough; Eastern Alaska Range South of Trims Camp

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON AKDT TODAY

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued April 12 at 6:12AM AKDT until April 12 at 10:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow and blowing snow occuring. Storm total snow accumulations of 8 to 12 inches. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph will reduce visibility to one half miles or less at times.
* WHERE...South Slopes Of The Central Brooks Range.
* WHEN...Until 10 PM AKDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow will continue today with another 2 to 4 inches accumulation. South winds will turn north this afternoon and increase causing blowing snow. The strong north winds and blowing snow will continue into this evening and then decrease late tonight with visibility improving late tonight.
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Slopes Of The Central Brooks Range

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 PM AKDT THIS EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 12 at 10:10AM EDT by NWS Albany NY
entry.summary:
At 1009 AM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along a line extending from 9 miles west of Moffitt Beach Campground to near Stratford. Movement was north at 45 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects.
Locations impacted include... Indian Lake, Speculator, Lake Pleasant, Stratford, Blue Mountain Lake, Brown Tract Pond Campground, Lake Durant Campground, Eighth Lake Campground, Lewey Lake Campground, Forked Lake Public Campground, Raquette Lake, Golden Beach Campground, Moffitt Beach Campground, Oppenheim, Oregon, Eagle Nest, Perkins Clearing, Clockmill Corners, Quaker Beach, and Lotville.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Hamilton; Southern Herkimer; Southern Fulton; Northern Fulton

cap:parameter.value: STRONG THUNDERSTORMS WILL IMPACT HAMILTON...WESTERN FULTON AND EAST CENTRAL HERKIMER COUNTIES THROUGH 1045 AM EDT

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued April 12 at 10:07AM EDT until April 12 at 1:00PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
At 1007 AM EDT, Rain, high winds, and temperatures into the 50s around the White Mountains is supporting rapid snowmelt. This will cause steep mountain streams to rise quickly and flood area roads.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by rain and snowmelt.
SOURCE...Gauges.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Conway, Berlin, Littleton, Lancaster, Fryeburg, Bethlehem, Lincoln, Haverhill, Franconia and Errol.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Carroll, NH; Coos, NH; Grafton, NH

cap:parameter.value: FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 1 PM EDT THIS AFTERNOON FOR NORTHERN CARROLL, SOUTHERN COOS AND NORTHERN GRAFTON COUNTIES

entry.title: Coastal Flood Warning issued April 12 at 10:07AM EDT until April 12 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...One to two feet of inundation above ground level in low lying areas due to tidal flooding.
* WHERE...Shoreline in Anne Arundel County.
* WHEN...Until 2 PM EDT this afternoon, especially around the time of high tide.
* IMPACTS...At 3.5 feet, water reaches the floor of the Maritime Museum in Annapolis, begins to cover Bowyer Road on the Naval Academy campus, and numerous businesses on Dock Street are flooded, along with the City Dock parking lot. Bayside Beach begins to flood around Harbor Rd and Lake Dr.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Tides two to two and a half feet above normal. The next high tide at Annapolis U.S. Naval Academy is at 8:56 PM.

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 2 PM EDT THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: Coastal Flood Warning issued April 12 at 10:07AM EDT until April 12 at 3:00PM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...One to two feet of inundation above ground level in low lying areas due to tidal flooding.
* WHERE...Shoreline in Southern Baltimore County and the city of Baltimore.
* WHEN...Until 3 PM EDT this afternoon, especially around the time of high tide.
* IMPACTS...At 4.5 feet, the end of Ann Street begins to flood. The concrete promenade at Fells Point is flooded, along with the boardwalk at the Maritime Park water taxi stop. Thames Street is flooded, and much of the promenade in the Inner Harbor is flooded. At 3.8 feet, water covers yards and approaches homes in the Bowleys Quarters area.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Tides two and a half to three feet above normal. The next high tide at Fort McHenry Baltimore is at 10:17 AM.

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM EDT THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: Coastal Flood Warning issued April 12 at 10:07AM EDT until April 12 at 5:00PM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...One to two feet of inundation above ground level in low lying areas due to tidal flooding.
* WHERE...Shoreline in the District of Columbia, Arlington County, and the City of Alexandria.
* WHEN...Until 5 PM EDT this afternoon, especially around the time of high tide.
* IMPACTS...The unprotected area on the Southwest Waterfront at the DC Seafood Market is expected to flood. Water is expected to approach parts of the Hains Point Loop Road, but it will likely be closed. Water is expected to approach buildings near King Street and Union Street.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Tides two to two and a half feet above normal. The next high tide at Alexandria is at 11:48 AM. The next high tide at Washington Channel is at 11:30 AM.

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 PM EDT THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 12 at 9:07AM CDT by NWS Little Rock AR
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following river in Arkansas...
Ouachita River At Thatcher L&D affecting Bradley, Calhoun and Union Counties.
Ouachita River At Camden affecting Ouachita and Calhoun Counties.
For the Ouachita River...including Jones Mill Dcp, Arkadelphia, Camden, Thatcher L&D...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Ouachita River at Thatcher L&D.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 83.0 feet, Access to oil and gas rigs and to timber is flooded. Calhoun County Road 131 is completely under water leading to old Lock 8 river access.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 AM CDT Friday the stage was 83.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to 84.5 feet Monday morning. - Flood stage is 79.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bradley, AR; Calhoun, AR; Union, AR

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

* WHAT...Blizzard conditions expected. Additional snow accumulations of 1 to 2 inches. Winds gusting to 40 mph.
* WHERE...Baldwin Peninsula.
* WHEN...Until 5 PM AKDT this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. Snow drifts will form.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow, blowing snow, and increasing winds are expected to develop about 7AM today and continue through noon. Conditions should gradually improve this afternoon as falling snow ends and visibility increases. Winds will diminish tonight.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued April 12 at 10:03AM EDT until April 12 at 6:00PM EDT by NWS Indianapolis IN
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of central Indiana, including the following counties, Hamilton, Hancock, Madison, Marion and Tipton.
* WHEN...Until 600 PM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. River or stream flows are elevated and some streams remain out of their banks.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1001 AM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain. Minor flooding is already occurring in the advisory area. Between 2.5 and 4 inches of rain have fallen. - This includes the following streams and drainages... Brandywine Creek, Fall Creek, Mud Creek, Pipe Creek, Sand Creek - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Indianapolis, Anderson, Carmel, Fishers, Noblesville, Lawrence, Greenfield, Alexandria, Westfield, Cumberland, Cicero, McCordsville, Pendleton, Fortville, Chesterfield, Ingalls, Lapel, Edgewood, Frankton and Arcadia. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued April 12 at 9:54AM EDT until April 12 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Up to one foot of inundation above ground level in low- lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways, mainly across the back bays.
* WHERE...Ocean and Coastal Ocean.
* WHEN...Until 8 PM EDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of lots, parks, and roads with only isolated road closures expected.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Flooding is generally expected to be on the back bays where water remains trapped. Minor flooding is expected along northern Barnegat Bay for the next two high tide cycles, especially in tidal locations near Mantoloking and Bayshore. Tidal flooding is not expected along the ocean- side or for much of the south end of Barnegat Bay.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 12 at 9:52AM EDT until April 13 at 5:00AM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Pittsburgh PA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Pennsylvania...
Clarion River At Cooksburg affecting Jefferson PA, Clarion and Forest Counties.
.Heavy rain fell across much of western Pennsylvania over the past 18 hours, resulting in rapid rises on area streams and creeks.
Runoff from these rains is forecast to cause the Clarion River and Cooksburg to exceed minor flood stage.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Clarion River at Cooksburg.
* WHEN...From this afternoon to late tonight.
* IMPACTS...At 13.0 feet, Macbeth Cabins flood and water reaches River Road near the State Park office At 14.0 feet, About 1 foot of water covers River Road near the Cook Forest State Park office.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:00 AM EDT Friday the stage was 11.6 feet. - Bankfull stage is 13.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage this afternoon to a crest of 13.5 feet this evening. It will then fall below flood stage late this evening. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 13.4 feet on 09/09/2004. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 12 at 9:42AM EDT until April 16 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Suwannee River At White Springs affecting Hamilton, Suwannee and Columbia Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/forecasts.php?wfo=jax.
The next statement will be issued Saturday morning at 945 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Suwannee River at White Springs.
* WHEN...From Sunday morning to early Tuesday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 70.0 feet, Water reaches the top of the boat ramp at US 41 in Hamilton County. At 72.0 feet, Water reaches the top of the bank at the park at US 41 in Hamilton County. All public boat ramps between White Springs and Suwannee Springs are subject to closure. At 74.0 feet, The parking lot to the Blue Sink launch floods in Suwannee County. The area is not accessible above this level. Flooding expands into the park at US 41 in Hamilton County. At 75.0 feet, Access to White Springs Swim House is impassible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 AM EDT Friday the stage was 68.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage Sunday morning to a crest of 74.3 feet Sunday evening. entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 12 at 9:41AM EDT until April 12 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Portions of northwest, west central, and western Pennsylvania, including the following counties, in northwest Pennsylvania, western Forest, Mercer and Venango. In west central Pennsylvania, central Armstrong, Butler and Clarion. In western Pennsylvania, Lawrence.
* WHEN...Until 800 PM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Numerous roads remain closed due to flooding. Streams continue to rise due to excess runoff from earlier rainfall.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 941 AM EDT, emergency management reported heavy rain in the warned area. Flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. Between 1.5 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... entry.summary:

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 12 at 9:41AM EDT until April 15 at 4:00PM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Georgia...
Alapaha River At Statenville affecting Echols County.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/forecasts.php?wfo=jax.
The next statement will be issued Saturday morning at 945 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Alapaha River at Statenville.
* WHEN...From late tonight to Monday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 92.0 feet, Griner Road in Mayday begins to flood. This isolates 10 homes in the area. Flooding along the road subsides 2 to 3 days after the river crests in Statenville or when the river falls below 96 feet. At 100.0 feet, The boat ramp near the gauge and adjacent parking lot are flooded. At 103.0 feet, Homes along the river in Statenville and Griner Road become inundated.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:45 AM EDT Friday the stage was 98.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late tonight to a crest of 101.0 feet early Sunday morning. It will then fall below flood stage late Monday morning. - Flood stage is 100.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.summary:

entry.title: Flood Watch issued April 12 at 3:16AM HST until April 12 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FOR KAUAI COUNTY THROUGH LATE THIS AFTERNOON...
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Niihau and Kauai.
* WHEN...Through this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Significant flooding may occur due to the overflow of streams and drainages. Roads in several areas may be closed, along with property damage in urban or low lying spots due to runoff. Landslides may also occur in areas with steep terrain.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - A slow-moving band of heavy showers and thunderstorms will remain nearly stationary over Kauai and Niihau today, bringing the potential for additional flash flooding to areas that have already seen a significant amount of rainfall.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued April 12 at 9:13AM EDT until April 12 at 3:00PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
FFWGYX
The National Weather Service in Gray has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Rain and Snowmelt in... Franklin County in western Maine... Northern Oxford County in western Maine...
* Until 300 PM EDT.
* At 913 AM EDT, Heavy rain was moving into the Western Maine Mountains. This rain will accelerate snowmelt leading to flash flooding. The expectation is that rainfall rates and coverage of heavy rain may increase going through midday. An additional 2 to 3 inches of rain may occur locally.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by heavy rain and snowmelt.
SOURCE...Radar and automated gauges.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small stream. Excessive runoff in steep terrain could also result in washouts.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding are focused over snow covered locations including... Farmington, Newry, Bethel, Eustis, Rangeley, Andover and Carrabassett Valley.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 12 at 9:12AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River At Three Rivers Estates affecting Suwannee, Gilchrist and Columbia Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/forecasts.php?wfo=jax.
The next statement will be issued Saturday morning at 915 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santa Fe River at Three Rivers Estates.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins on SW Santa Fe Drive south of Santa Fe Road in Columbia County. At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River. At 19.8 feet, Waters begins to affect homes in the Hollingsworth Bluff area at State Route 47. At 20.0 feet, Access to homes on Santa Fe Road below SW Riverside Avenue becomes restricted in Columbia. Flooding begins on Santa Fe and Wilson Springs Road. At 21.0 feet, Homes are surrounded on River Run Road in Suwannee County. Structures flood along Santa Fe Road west of Idaho Parkway in Columbia County. At 22.0 feet, River Run Road at 29th loop floods in Suwannee County. Santa Fe Road in Columbia County is inaccessible. At 23.0 feet, Homes are inaccessible along River Run Road in Suwannee County west of 33rd Road. At 24.0 feet, Flooding expands across the area affecting numerous homes on Santa Fe Road and SW Riverside Avenue in Columbia County. Access to 29th loop in Suwannee County becomes restricted.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:00 AM EDT Friday the stage was 18.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to 22.1 feet Thursday evening. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Columbia, FL; Gilchrist, FL; Suwannee, FL

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued April 12 at 6:56AM MDT until April 12 at 8:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING FROM NOON TO 8 PM TODAY FOR PARTS OF CENTRAL AND EASTERN NM DUE TO STRONG WIND, LOW HUMIDITY, AND AN UNSTABLE ATMOSPHERE...
.South and southwest winds will strengthen today ahead of an upper level trough approaching from the southwest. Minimum humidity will fall to near 10% with above normal temperatures, wind gusts up to 40 mph, and high Haines indices. Surface winds will taper off after sunset Friday to alleviate critical fire weather.
* AREA AND TIMING...Middle Rio Grande Valley (106), Sandia and Manzano Mountains (Zone 124), Central Highlands (Zone 125), Northeast Highlands (Zone 123), and Northeast Plains (Zone 104) today from noon until 8 PM MDT.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...South and southwest 15 to 30 mph with gusts up to 40 mph, except up to 45 mph across northeast areas.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...9 to 11 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northeast Plains; Middle Rio Grande Valley; Northeast Highlands; Sandia and Manzano Mountains; Central Highlands

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued April 12 at 2:47AM HST until April 12 at 6:00AM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
FFWHFO
The National Weather Service in Honolulu has extended the
* Flash Flood Warning for... The island of Kauai in Kauai County
* Until 600 AM HST.
* At 247 AM HST, the most intense rainfall has moved southeast of Kauai, but rain rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour continue over the southern side of the island. The Kauai Emergency Management Agency reported that evacuations have taken place near Koloa and Wailua. Additional rainfall is expected to continue over the next several hours.
HAZARD...Heavy rain producing life threatening flash flooding.
SOURCE...Emergency management.
IMPACT...Significant and life threatening flooding in drainages, streams, rivers, roads, properties, and other low lying areas. Multiple public road closures expected, as well as landslides in steep terrain.
* This warning includes the entire island of Kauai.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 12 at 5:50AM EDT until April 13 at 6:00PM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Pittsburgh PA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in West Virginia...Ohio... Pennsylvania...
Ohio River At Moundsville affecting Marshall County.
Ohio River At Wheeling affecting Ohio and Belmont Counties.
Ohio River At Pittsburgh affecting Allegheny County.
Ohio River At Powhatan Point affecting Marshall, Monroe and Belmont Counties.
Ohio River At Pike Island affecting Ohio, Jefferson OH and Belmont Counties.
Ohio River At Hannibal affecting Wetzel, Monroe and Tyler Counties.
Ohio River At Montgomery affecting Columbiana, Hancock and Beaver Counties.
.An intense storm system moving up the Ohio Valley has produced widespread moderate to heavy rain to our area. Rainfall amounts across southwest Pennsylvania and the northern panhandle of West Virginia range from 1.25
This heavy rain is resulting in significant runoff that is causing rivers to rise rapidly. On the Ohio river, many locations are forecast to reach or exceed minor flood stage.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Ohio River at Pittsburgh.
* WHEN...From this evening to tomorrow evening.
* IMPACTS...At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flow onto the Monongahela Parking Wharf. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to flow onto the North Shore riverwalk between the stadiums. At 19.5 feet, The Monongahela Parking Wharf is completely flooded. At 20.0 feet, Water is up to one foot deep in the lower areas of the North Shore Riverwalk. At 22.0 feet, The Tenth Street Bypass floods. At 22.5 feet, The fountain plaza is flooded. At 24.0 feet, Water enters the outer pool of the fountain. At 24.9 feet, Water entes the inner pool of the fountain. At 25.0 feet, The Parkway Central (also known as the bathtub) is closed by flooding. Lower North Side businesses are affected. At 26.0 feet, State Correctional Institution Pittsburgh is impacted.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 5:30 AM EDT Friday the stage was 20.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 18.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this evening to a crest of 25.2 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage early tomorrow afternoon. - Flood stage is 25.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 25.3 feet on 12/02/2010. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

* WHEN...Until noon EDT today.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Warning issued April 12 at 5:47AM EDT until April 12 at 12:00PM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Around two feet of inundation above ground level in low- lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways.
* WHERE...Dorchester, Wicomico and Somerset Counties.
* WHEN...Until noon EDT today.
* IMPACTS...Widespread flooding of vulnerable areas will result in an elevated threat of property damage to homes and businesses near the waterfront and shoreline. Flooding will extend inland from the waterfront along tidal rivers and bays resulting in some road closures and flooding of vehicles.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 12 at 5:41AM EDT until April 12 at 11:30AM EDT by NWS Boston/Norton MA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of western Massachusetts, including the following counties, Franklin, Hampden and Hampshire.
* WHEN...Until 1130 AM EDT.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 534 AM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated moderate rain falling over the warned area. The Mill River was becoming swollen due to heavy rainfall. At 500 AM, its level was at 10.49 ft with flood stage set at 11 ft. The river is expected to rise over flood stage, resulting in lowland flooding along the Oxbow floodplain in Northhampton, as well as flooding portions of the River Walk at Smith College. Additional minor flooding could develop in more urbanized and poor drainage areas as rounds of showers move across the warned area this morning. Between 0.5 and 1 inch of rain has fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are possible in the warned area. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Springfield, Chicopee, Holyoke, Amherst, Northampton, West Springfield, Ludlow, South Hadley, Easthampton, Granby, Southampton, Hadley, Hatfield, Williamsburg, Westhampton, Whately, Chesterfield and Goshen. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Franklin, MA; Hampden, MA; Hampshire, MA

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 1130 AM EDT THIS MORNING

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued April 12 at 5:03AM EDT until April 12 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 5 to 8 feet in the surf zone. For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous rip currents and large breaking waves expected in the surf zone.
* WHERE...West Carteret and East Carteret Counties.
* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, until 2 PM EDT Friday. For the Beach Hazards Statement, from Friday morning through Friday evening.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and back injuries.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide, which will occur around 5 AM and 4 PM Friday.

For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous rip currents, large breaking waves expected, and strong longshore currents in the surf zone.

Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and back injuries. Strong longshore currents will create dangerous swimming conditions.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide, which will occur around 5 AM and 4 PM Friday.

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued April 12 at 5:03AM EDT until April 12 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways. For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 6 to 9 feet expected in the surf zone. For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous rip currents, large breaking waves expected, and strong longshore currents in the surf zone.
* WHERE...Ocracoke Island.
* WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, until 8 PM EDT Friday. For the Beach Hazards Statement, from Friday morning through Friday evening.
* IMPACTS...The vulnerable portion of NC-12 on the northern end of the island, will likely see inundation from ocean overwash which could close the road. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and back injuries. Strong longshore currents will create dangerous swimming conditions.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide, which will occur around 5 AM and 4 PM Friday.

* WHERE...Hatteras Island.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued April 12 at 3:46AM EDT until April 12 at 4:00PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
Moderate to heavy rain will fall on a deep, primed snowpack in the mountains leading to increased snowmelt. Flows in rivers will likely increase quickly as a result and may reach critical levels.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by rain and snowmelt continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of Maine, including the following areas, Central Somerset, Northern Franklin, Northern Oxford, Southern Franklin, Southern Oxford and Southern Somerset and northern New Hampshire, including the following areas, Northern Carroll, Northern Coos, Northern Grafton, Southern Coos and Southern Grafton.
* WHEN...Through this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Heavy rainfall along with warm and humid conditions will cause rapid melting of the snowpack from the foothills northward. This will increase runoff into streams and rivers. Moderate to heavy rainfall over partially frozen ground will support the potential for flash flooding as well as river flooding. Disruption to travel is likely on Friday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Oxford; Northern Franklin; Central Somerset; Southern Oxford; Southern Franklin; Southern Somerset; Northern Coos; Southern Coos; Northern Grafton; Northern Carroll; Southern Grafton

entry.title: Flood Watch issued April 12 at 2:27AM EDT until April 13 at 12:00AM EDT by NWS Caribou ME
entry.summary:
Rain falling on snow in wooded areas will lead to snow melt and increasing runoff. Flows in streams and creeks will rise Friday into Friday evening and may locally reach bankfull or cause minor flooding.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by rain and snowmelt continues to be possible.
* WHERE...A portion of Central Highlands Maine, including the following areas, Central Piscataquis and Southern Piscataquis.
* WHEN...From 8 AM EDT this morning through this evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of small rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Rainfall totals of 1 to 1.5 inches with locally higher amounts can be expected across the area Friday into Friday evening. The rain will combine with snowmelt up to the equivalent of 2 inches of liquid. The combination of rain and snowmelt will cause streams and creeks to rise and may result in minor flooding. - For flood safety visit www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 8 AM EDT THIS MORNING THROUGH THIS EVENING

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued April 11 at 10:58PM PDT by NWS Elko NV
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Elko has issued a Flood Advisory for the following rivers in Nevada...
Bruneau River At Rowland affecting Elko County.
.Warm temperatures will melt high mountain snowpack and increase river flows.
For the Bruneau River...including Rowland...elevated river levels are forecast.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by snowmelt is expected.
* WHERE...Bruneau River at Rowland.
* WHEN...From this evening until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 7.0 feet, Minor flooding of Forest Service roads. Recreational use becomes limited.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:25 PM PDT Thursday the stage was 6.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 6.0 feet. - Forecast...No forecast is available for this location. However, warm temperatures continue to enhance afternoon snowmelt, with rises at the river gauge most pronounced in the late evening and overnight hours. This pattern is expected to continue on both Friday and Saturday. Cooler temperatures Sunday into next week will slow the rate of snowmelt. - Action stage is 6.0 feet. - Flood stage is 7.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 11 at 10:37PM EDT until April 12 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Ohio...
Stillwater Creek At Uhrichsville affecting Tuscarawas County.
Muskingum River At Coshocton affecting Coshocton County.
.An intense storm system is moving through the Ohio River Valley spreading moderate rainfall across the region. The runoff from this rainfall will be sufficient to cause Stillwater Creek at Uhrichsville and the Muskingum River at Coshocton to rise above flood stage.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Stillwater Creek at Uhrichsville.
* WHEN...Until tomorrow evening.
* IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, Stillwater Creek comes out of its banks in several locations resulting in overflowing in poor drainage areas. Minor flooding of low lying areas begins. At 11.5 feet, Flood waters of Stillwater Creek will reach the intersection of East 12th Street and North Main Street in Uhrichsville and approach Newport Street. Little Stillwater Creek will flood most of Phac Park along with portions of Wilson Road in Dennison.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 10.3 feet. - Bankfull stage is 7.6 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:00 PM EDT Thursday was 10.3 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 10.4 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage early tomorrow afternoon. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 11.1 feet on 11/13/2022. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 11 at 10:37PM EDT until April 15 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Ohio...
Stillwater Creek At Uhrichsville affecting Tuscarawas County.
Muskingum River At Coshocton affecting Coshocton County.
.An intense storm system is moving through the Ohio River Valley spreading moderate rainfall across the region. The runoff from this rainfall will be sufficient to cause Stillwater Creek at Uhrichsville and the Muskingum River at Coshocton to rise above flood stage.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Muskingum River at Coshocton.
* WHEN...Until early Monday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 13.0 feet, Water reaches low lying areas between Tuscarawas and Walhonding Rivers just upstream of the confluence of the two rivers. At 15.0 feet, Low areas are flooded and water reaches a few homes along Route 16 south of Coshocton and along County Route 1A north of Coshocton. At 16.0 feet, Flood waters begin to affect the Lake Park area along the Walhonding River and begins backwater flooding along Mill Creek north of Lake Park and along Route 83. Flood waters will begin to enter yards in low-lying areas along County Route 1A. At 18.0 feet, Moderate flooding occurs along County Route 1A and lower areas along Route 16 south. Widespread flooding occurs from the Lake Park area south to near the intersection of Routes 83 and 36. Homes around North Water Street in Coshocton floods.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 15.7 feet. - Bankfull stage is 13.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:00 PM EDT Thursday was 15.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 16.3 feet tomorrow evening. It will then fall below flood stage Monday morning. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 18.0 feet on 03/20/2019. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flash Flood Watch issued April 11 at 3:08PM MDT until April 16 at 9:00PM MDT by NWS Salt Lake City UT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash Flooding caused by a potential dam or levee failure continues to be possible at the Panguitch Lake Dam.
* WHERE...A portion of Utah, including the following areas, Southern Mountains and Upper Sevier River Valleys.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...Dam failure may result in flash flooding of low-lying areas below the dam including the west side of the city of Panguitch.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - A Level 2 Emergency Situation indicates that there is a potential for dam failure. While there is no immediate threat to public safety, the situation could rapidly evolve. Officials are closely monitoring the dam and are prepared to escalate their response if necessary.
- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.summary:
...GUSTY WINDS AND DRY VEGETATION WILL MAINTAIN A HIGH FIRE THREAT...
* WIND...East wind 10 to 20 mph with afternoon gusts to 25 mph. Winds will be higher across higher terrain.
* HUMIDITY...Down to 55 to 65 percent at times, mainly from late morning until sunset.
* IMPACTS...any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended. Conditions will ease during the nighttime hours.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 11 at 12:06PM MDT by NWS Pocatello ID
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Idaho...
Portneuf River at Pocatello affecting Bannock County.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...The Portneuf River at Pocatello.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 8.5 feet, Sections of Sacajawea Park will be under water and the trail is usually closed at this level. Marsh Creek near Inkom may also be over its banks. At 9.2 feet, Flooding of low lying agricultural land and pasture will occur in the Inkom and Blackrock areas. Lowland flooding is likely along sections of the river between Portneuf Gap and the Cheyenne Avenue Bridge in Pocatello. At 9.4 feet, Water will encroach around sitting benches near the river at the Pacific Recycling Trailhead. At 10.0 feet, Significant flooding of agricultural land will occur from the Inkom and Blackrock areas. Lowland flooding will occur along sections of the river in Pocatello from Portneuf Gap to the Cheyenne Avenue Bridge and downstream of the concrete channel beginning at Sacajawea Park.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:45 AM Thursday the stage was 8.3 feet. - Forecast...Due to strongly warming temperatures over the next several days accelerating snowmelt, the river is expected to rise above minor flood stage (8.5 feet) by tonight and continue to rise above moderate flood stage (10.0 feet) by Saturday afternoon, cresting at 10.7 feet by Monday morning. This represents a slightly faster forecasted rise compared to the previous warning update. - Flood stage is 8.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 10.7 feet on 01/09/1973. - For flood safety information, visit www.weather.gov/safety/flood.

entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Indiana...Kentucky...Illinois...

.Minor flooding continues along portions of the Lower Ohio River from Newburgh Dam to Shawneetown.
